segments.text: We have a complaint here against you that you're going to have a closed court against the Fort Jackson Five, and I said, that's exactly right.
I said, I thought all you people in Washington knew that.
Well, they said, well, Secretary of Defense and Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs feels that it should be opened.
I said, I guess you misunderstood me.
I said, the court is closed, and if you want it open, you get yourself another boy down here to command this place.
That's what you told him?
That's what I told him.
Of course, that was going back to the Secretary of Defense.
That went back to the Secretary of Defense.
The court remained closed.
Well...
They were all found guilty.
Of what charge?
For disrupting the military operations and for anti-communist activities within the armed forces.
I mean for communist activities.
Anti-American activities.
Anti-American activities, yeah.
And there were eight or ten charges on there.
I don't remember now what it was.
defiance of rules and standing order and regulation, misconduct, and so on and so forth like that in public places.
And they were found guilty and given undesirable discharge or dishonorable discharges depending on the seriousness of each individual.
And then they turned around and sued me in the federal courts for denying their rights on the First Amendment.
And the Secretary of the Army and I were tried
And this is the first case we tried in the federal courts.
I was tried in the federal court along with the Secretary of the Army.
And a federal court ruled that you could not operate a military force as a common ordinary civilian organization.
from the standpoint of discipline and authority of the commander-in-chief, and that we were, the Secretary of the Army and I, were acquitted.
And they appealed that.
And we got a two-to-one vote in our favor in the Fourth Circuit Court in Richmond.
And that was over with, and those guys were out.

And believe it or not, one went to Massachusetts and ran for the Congress up there under the Socialist Workers Party and the head leader stayed in Georgia and ran for the Congress under the Social Workers Party of the First District of Washington.
But that was an episode in my life where, you know,

have got to stand up to what you believe in and be damned what the intent of your superiors might be from the standpoint of interfering with your responsibilities which you've been assigned to and by God when they do they either they either get in my view get somebody else to do the damn job or leave you alone.
And they left me alone.
But it set the example.
The case set the example for the rest of the United States during this critical period of communist disruption and burning of buildings and total destruction, anarchy within a democracy.
That's a hell of a thing to happen in a democracy, isn't it?
God damn.
Did you have any other examples of disorderly conduct?
Out of the ordinary disorderly conduct?
Oh.
Or for the most part were they just the usual or the usual routine sort of thing?
Nothing uncommon to everyday life.
Did you ever, with these Fort Jackson Five, did you ever have any talks or discussion with them?
No, no.
Did you ever interview them?
No, God no.
Ask them what they were doing or why?
No, no, no.
Weren't you curious?
Well, you get all that information anyway.
You got ways and means of finding out all this information, you know.
So you don't need to talk to them.
You just don't, you never want to give a communist element the privilege of, of being honored with your presence, you see.
So, that,
You'd be surprised how many congressmen, how much support from the Congress you can get from a communist element in this country.
What do you mean?
A congressman writing you and saying, what are you doing to this fine young man?
We've just heard that you locked up this fine young man.
What's the matter with you?
And what they're talking about is they're supporting a commie.
See?
And you say, well Jesus Christ, how in the hell can the people elect a joker like that to represent them in the United States Congress?
Through ignorance?
He was ignorant in the first place.
He really didn't
intend to support communism.
Sometimes you feel like that they do, but I don't think they do.
But it's the sort of thing that, that's the reason I asked you yesterday about what we had found at A&M back some time ago, what the indications were.
Well, you left there in 1970 and you went up to command the entire Army in Alaska.
What are the responsibilities up there?
Responsibilities are to command about a division of, at that time, about a division of Arctic trained soldiers and Eskimo scouts.

with intelligence activities scattered along that part of the front, along the barren straits, and to provide external security and support to internal police forces, and to train the soldiers in the art of winter warfare, skiing, glacier

training on glacier ice, movement on the glaciers, mountain climbing, arctic scouting, the art of scouting, parachuting in toward the North Pole, and survival and recovery, and the use of helicopters and snowmobiles and other types of equipment.
and most of your training you wait until the weather is minus fifty degrees for your winter exercises and you work very closely with the Canadian military and you exchange units back and forth.
The exercise that I had during the winter of 1970 was for about six weeks in which I had a commando regiment
airborne commando regiment out of Canada joined us.
I had about five thousand in the exercise.

They sent me about fifteen hundred and we were to experiment with the use of helicopters in air mobile operations during the heavy winter and the temperature had to be minus fifty to minus seventy-five in order for us to and we learned a tremendous amount about
cold soaking of vehicles.
We know that we only, at those temperatures, we only get about 10 minutes of work per hour out of a soldier.
We know that we have a high number of casualties because you can't get them to go urinate or defecate because flesh burns, third degree burns, in 30 seconds at that temperature.
We know that if you cut your helicopter off, it'll cold soak in 15 minutes to the point it'll take you two hours with Herman Nelson heaters in order to get it to where it'll start again.
So you never turn off the engine, you see, helicopter engine, when you're flying out in the field.
We know that the commanding general designed his own uniform.
That's me in the uniform Wade
less than four pounds while he survived at minus 75.
The soldiers had to have 96 pounds of clothing on to survive at that temperature.
Why?
Was it a different material?
Yes, totally different material.
I designed this uniform.
It was a two-piece form-fitting goose-down underwear.
with zippers all over the place so you know you can without taking it off and without exposure.
Followed by a wind-resistant piece of cloth that was finally found of a tins line, a tins line which is real hard, waterproof, windproof, and that in the form of a one-piece coverall again lined with
with goose down on the inside.
The result of that is you find today a product called Gore-Tex, G-R-E-T-E-X, okay?
Yeah, by Gorman.
Yeah.
No, wait a minute.
What's the guy's name?
His name is Gore, isn't it?
Yeah, yeah.
So, it's Gore-Tex.
That's the forerunner of this uniform I had.
Gore-Tex is a waterproof
Yeah, that's right.
And hard as hell.
You can't cut it with a knife.
And then I had a same sort of headgear with wolf fur on the outside, which would not permit snow to melt on my face.
I was able to negotiate
with just a small amount of weight.
Well, the problem resolved itself around the fact that you can't get enough goose down to equip a division of troops.
It just isn't available, and I put the Natick Laboratories up in Massachusetts requirement on them to come up with the material to replace goose down.

It's my understanding that they've been able to do that now, but it's been one hell of an expensive proposition to try to come up with a synthetic that produces the same warmth capability, protection capability as goose down.
Is that how we got things like hollow film?
Yes, yes, yes.
Those are all the requirements.
originated out of those exercises over the years, not only that one but others.
Probably the most effective vehicle for moving across the snow is a surface effects vehicle.
Surface effects vehicle, as you know.
That's a vehicle that operates on air cushion.
Yeah, on air cushion.
Helicopters, we found, created snowstorms.
We'd be able to set down a piece of artillery
The normal procedure is to sit down next to it and let the 15 men off it and the ammunition that's going to run that artillery piece.

But in letting the ammunition bag under the artillery piece that slung down under the helicopter on the ground, it created such a snowstorm that the helicopter had to fly away and wait until the storm subsided before he could come back
and create another storm, but go ahead and sit down and let the men out.
So we learned a tremendous amount of what you need to do.
One thing we know that we have to do if we're going to have that kind of operations in Alaska in the snow, we know that we have to go stabilize the snow.
How do you do that?
Well, you spray it with a chemical.
and stabilize the snow so you can sit down without creating these clouds.
Of course, if you're doing this operation near the enemy, you're tipping your hand because he can see the snow clouds that you're creating.
I would say that 10% at temperatures of minus 50 to minus 75
Ten percent of the effort is fighting and ninety percent is survival.
That's just what I would think.
I would think that the probability of ever having battle in that type of atmosphere would be really slim unless we were talking about Particularly ground action.
Yeah, exactly.
I think you'd have to concentrate primarily on air capability.
Was this aimed toward Siberia?
Well, this is aimed toward defending ourselves against attacks from Siberia across the Bering Strait.
Tell me about relations of the Canadians and the quality of their troops and officers.
Their troops and officers are very, very high quality.
As a matter of fact, this particular regiment had two squadrons.
Instead of saying battalions, they were talking about squadrons.
And one was French and one was English.
High order of professionalism, very high order of professionalism.
And this particular regiment trades off every three years from an English regimental commander to a French-speaking regimental commander.
Well, this regiment had a lot of capability for insurgency, for scouting, for operations behind lines, supporting people on the flanks, for internal security purposes.
It's a tremendous capability to have in that one regiment.
But they are not unlike other armies in the world who have
less responsibility in the world than the United States.
They have so very few, so little strength, but what they have is number one first class in my view, and they've got some top-notch officers.
I have been to school with their officers, and I have great admiration and respect for them.
In fact, they just
I'd be willing to fight under their command or along beside them or in front of them or behind them or wherever you say, anytime, anyplace in the world.
That's how good they are.
And they have a brigade in Europe at a part of their NATO commitment.
And I had visited that unit in 1976 and they had one of the
finance brigade commanders there was in Europe.
He was just totally outstanding, along with all of his subordinates.
So I can't speak with nothing but praise and admiration for Canadian forces, but they're awfully small and they don't have very much.
I suppose it's
gets back to money and it also gets back to what do they need to take care of themselves when they got a United States down south that's damn sure not going to interfere with what they're doing.
Now you were controversial when you were down in South Carolina
Do you think that they moved you all the way up to Alaska to put you on ice, so to speak?
Maybe so, but I inherited another situation in Alaska which I spent many months cleaning out.
Oh, well what was that?
The Mafia, the civilian Mafia had penetrated the aviation supply company
Fairbanks.
And they were stealing off, with the assistance of some of the military personnel, thousands and thousands of dollars worth of supplies.
Really?
Yeah.
How'd you find out about this?
Well, this stuff is showing up all over the place, the country.
U.S. Army equipment is showing up in places it shouldn't be showing up.
Oh yeah, that's right.
And so, with the aid of a little help from Washington, I called for some fifteen army auditors, special army auditors,
And about the same number of agents, trained agents, I was able to penetrate this business.
Cleaned it out.
Some of the mafia started killing themselves and disappearing before we got indictments in the federal court.
I cleaned that out.
And about that time... Federal FBI agents?
Yes.
Oh, yeah.
Oh, I worked very closely with them.
And my own CID, Criminal Investigations people too, from Washington, I had asked to be reinforced, unbeknownst to anybody, you know.
High quality, did you think the FBI was high quality?
Oh, absolutely, number one.
Just absolutely.
I've always had the greatest admiration for the FBI.
Now you get another assignment, another year in Vietnam.
I get seven days to get to Vietnam, General Abrams says.
Oh, is that how long?
Were you trying to get back?
No, I was trying to spend another year in Alaska after I'd cleaned this mess up so I could go fishing.
Get in a little fishing.
Did you have any time?
Oh, hell, I only got one
float trip of a couple of days, that's all I had.
Miss Hollingsworth, she enjoyed going down to Seward Bay and where we had a camp, Army had a camp, and catching silver salmon and that sort of stuff.
And I got a chance to go out one Sunday afternoon to Iliamna and I got a big rainbow down there.
I had very little time for that.
General Abrams called you up and said, General, Chief of Staff of the Army called me up and said, General Abrams wants you over there right away in seven days.
And I said, hell, I've got to get Miss Hollingsworth home.
Well, you better get moving.
So, my God, we just got things stirred up, and I got Miss H back home, and then I took off and got over there.
And what had happened there, we had a couple of disasters up on the DMZ.
And Abrams wanted me back over there.
They were receiving a lot of criticism about drugs amongst the soldiers.
He had had a fifth

The 5th Brigade, separate brigade, 5th Independent Brigade that was on the DMZ between North and South in a fire base and they created themselves a mess hall and they had all the guys in there eating and in comes a rocket and kills a big part of the people.
Total violation of how to secure yourself and to allow people to congregate in a place that's vulnerable to attack.
Murdered a bunch of people.
Then they had Mary Ann, Firebase Mary Ann, which is a part of the old Mealy Division, the 23rd Division, Marical Division, had the Mealy problems.
Well, they guys went to sleep in a fire base.
Communists overrun them, killed most of them.
And Abrams, I guess, thought that was the problem.
We better get the meanest son of a bitch in the world back over here.
That's why he called you?
Yeah, yeah.
Meanest son of a bitch in the world back over here to sort this out.
Is that what he told you when he got there?
Yeah, yeah.
He said, I want you to get up there and get it sorted out.
I said, well, I'll take a look at it.
He said, I don't want you looking at it.
I want you to sort it out.
Well, it had, deterioration had, you know, nothing to do.
The President of the United States and the Secretary of Defense and all the high moguls in Washington, plus all the Congress,
I went up north and you had 23rd Division up there and 101st Airborne Division.
And this separate brigade up there, bits and pieces of artillery scattered here and there.
And I became the deputy commander as a major general, deputy commander of the 24th Corps.
That's the emblem right there.
This is what they gave me when I lived up there.
24th Corps was commanded by a hell of a fine guy.
A nice guy.
What was his name?
His name was, I'd rather not call his name.
He was just a nice guy.
Nice guys don't win ballgames.
And he turned me loose.
He said, I know why you're here.
He was a three star?
Yeah, he was a three star.
You have the freedom of the run.
Well, I started sorting things out.
I found a battery of artillery that couldn't perform.
Remember now we were deactivating units and they were bringing them home and that sort of stuff.
I found a battery of artillery that was so hopped up on drugs
that rather than try to train it, I just deactivated it in place.
Took all the people away, sent them home, and deactivated it right there in the spot.
That bad off.
That bad off.
They couldn't have fired around in any direction anywhere.
Marijuana?
Marijuana.
So, uh,
I got very tough with them.
I went into the 101st Division.

I found rusty weapons and fire bases and here the division commander, I'd have the division commander and the brigade commander and the battalion commander and the whole sequence of command right there and here I am looking at a rusty rifle in a fire base and I said, inexcusable.
How's this guy gonna save his life with this thing and he won't shoot?
Well that's how lax things have gotten.
Well the only thing that saved us I guess was the fact that you had to leave.
In the meantime I knew Giep up there from intelligence reports was getting ready to pull off an onslaught
As we left, he was going to come in with all of his conventional capability and not a counterinsurgency role that he had been doing, but now he's ready.
He's got all the tanks and equipment, T-54, T-55 tanks, artillery, air defense weapons that the Soviets had sent him.
He's all set now to go conventional.

against the Vietnamization which was the Vietnamese plus a handful of Americans left and he struck on the 30th of March meantime here I am up there sorting things out and we're sending people home sending people home when Abrams relieves a major general who is more or less a commander of the third
Vietnamese Corps just outside of Saigon.
Abrams relieves him and by God I get instructions to go immediately so I go there immediately on the 15th of December.
That relief came as a result of an element of artillery on the Cambodian border
having a little conflict with a troop of cavalry, U.S. Cavalry, the 1st Cavalry Division, and the artillery soldiers got up and left their artillery pieces because they were scheduled to go home.
The U.S. Army?
Yeah, U.S.
They got up and left them, and here you are in the face of the enemy on the Cambodian border, the artillery pieces sitting there.
So the cavalry was sent up to guard the pieces, and they resented the hell out of that, of course.
Where did you find these soldiers?
I don't know whatever happened to them.
But anyway, that had happened and occurred and had been sorted out, but then I guess General Abrams had decided that that fellow needed to go home.
He must have been tired.
Actually, generals don't get tired, you know.
So, I go down there and take over that.
I inherit a three-star Third Vietnamese Corps commander who had been one hell of a guy as a regimental commander and as a division commander.

But I thought he was weak as hell as a corps commander and he had been fighting the war for twenty years and wounded seven or eight times and I guess what happens to a man you finally reach a point of no return and no end to what you've been doing for twenty years and you just finally reach a point where you're totally ineffective.
As a result of that I had to take over command of that Vietnamese corps because he was so sick
and so frightened that he couldn't eat and he couldn't sleep.
So instead of me being He was the three-star Vietnamese general.
Yeah, instead of me being his advisor, I became the commander.
I did it all.
And on the 30th of March, they assaulted Loc Ninh with new forces.
And then they moved to Arnlock, a province capital, in a big rubber plantation that was to become GEAP's headquarters for control in the South.
And they were to take that by the 18th of April and set up their new government down there.
I refused to let them have it.
And I had one Vietnamese, part of one Vietnamese division in there, plus some province forces of total strength was 6,800.
6,800 Vietnamese?
How many Americans?
About six.
About six?
Six Americans, yeah, advisors.
And they took on 49,000 starting on the 5th of April.
And they were totally surrounded.
And you were in there?
I went in and out.
By helicopter?
By helicopter.
And that was under siege from the 5th of April until I finally killed that formation the second time.
And Mr. Gieb decided that he no longer had an offensive capability on the 18th of May.
There was continuous, sporadic action all around, but I had totally destroyed his offensive capability.
And at that time, I had destroyed it twice.
I destroyed it first when he attacked with five divisions.
Tell me about this.
Well, they had five divisions that attacked 360 degrees around these guys, plus one artillery division.

which they'd brought in, and the artillery division beat to pieces all the Vietnamese artillery inside and destroyed the whole place of An Loc, a beautiful French province, you know, town headquarters, red tile roofs and all that sort of stuff.
Very French, modern place.
It was a province headquarters with 20,000 people in it.
They destroyed that, a large share of it.
They were supposed to have that on the 18th.

The 9th VC Division, those that we captured and killed of that division, had a clean uniform in his pack and they were going to be the parade forces on the 18th of April when they set up their new government and took over the South.
Well, with the use of B-52s and TAC air,
and some helicopter gunship.
And by the use of C-130s, I was able to keep ammunition supplies going in there.
And at the end of the first battle, which was over about the 16th or 17th, they were unable to attack me again until the 10th of May, at which time they brought down
40,000 more replacements plus 135 tanks, T-55 tanks.
At that time I counted my strength and I was down to about 3,000.

That included wounded because the Vietnamese refused to go in and take all these helicopters we'd give them and train them with for the last eight years, refused to go in and evacuate their own wounded.
Really?
The South Vietnamese?
The South Vietnamese refused to go in and back their own wounded.
Why was that?
Because they'd get the hell shot out of them.

And the other thing is they lost total control of their people and when they'd get a helicopter in there you had only about two seconds to sit down, load up, and get out before the incoming rockets and artillery.
The high day of rocket incoming fire on those forces was 5,800 rounds in a 24-hour period, which we think, for the density that we held on the 10th of May, we only had 100,000 meters by 2,000 meters.
That's all we had.
That was all that was left at Onlon.
We had that.
with probably 2,800 people, some of them afraid to shoot their weapons because they knew that if they were wounded, there was no medical capability.
And they knew that their own people wouldn't evacuate them.
And I was told that I could not afford to have any casualties because Vietnamization is working.

And I knew goddamn well how well Vietnamization was working because here I am in command of all 14 provinces plus all the regional forces and the popular forces in all the villages plus the five-division Vietnamese capability against now in the total and final analysis about 67 divisions of North Vietnamese around An Long.
And I'm catching hell from everybody.
And bad press.
And... Why bad press?
Well, press, for example, one time... During this battle?
Yeah, during the whole damn campaign, during April and May.
Well, one time I landed on the road, Highway 13, which had been cut off and blocked, which is our supply route in there, which caused
no ground element supply at all.
It had to all be by air, air droppable.
I was, I was standing out there and the BBC, I looked around and somebody had a microphone stuck between the legs.
Well, General, what are you going to do today?
Have you lost on lock?
I said, hell no, I haven't lost on lock.
And he said, well, what are you going to do today?
I said, I'm going to kill every one of these bastards before they get back into Cambodia.
And Jesus God, first thing I know, the Secretary of Defense, old Hubert Humphrey, who was a leftist son of a bitch, and a goddamn Catholic
Priest in Washington saying, you ought to relieve that guy.
He's trying to kill his enemy.
Can you imagine that?
Well, Abrams come out and he said, God damn it, you have to talk to the press.
I said, no, I don't have to talk to the press.
I avoid the goddamn press.
But when some son of a bitch sticks a microphone up between my legs, next time I'm going to shoot him.
He said, Jesus Christ, I'd rather you talk to him than shoot him.
One or another is bad enough.
Well, you know, you know, goddamned anti-American bastards in America or something else.
Anyway...
We went ahead and won that damn battle.
What about the second siege?
Oh, second siege, the second go at it.
You were telling me about the buildup.
Well, they got them all back together, and we started getting pressure on the 10th.
So I went out to see General Abrams.
He said, can you hold it?
I said, well, if I get enough firepower, I can.
I said, I don't have any troops hardly left the town.
I said, I got it.
Somehow or another, I got to get them to hold.
If I can just get them to hold, I'll kill the rest of the bastards myself.
But I've got to get them to hold.
He said, well, I got 125 sorties a day of B-52s.
He said, I've been thinking about giving all of them to you one day and then give them the next area over in

fuel up in the second core area of Viet Cong up in the hill country some help the next day and then up on the DMZ in the first core area in Da Nang area the next day and I said well god damn it if you do that it means three and I'll get them all tomorrow and then when I need them the next day they're out their B-52s are gone somewhere else I said I'm not so sure that I can stand that
But I said, by God, I'll accept that if you'll give them to me when I want them.
He said, well, when do you think you're going to be attacked?
I said, I think I'm going to be attacked at 5.30 on the morning of the 11th.
He said, why do you say that?
I said, because of the buildup and the pressures I'm getting all around the perimeter, tank movements and that sort of stuff.
And I said, if you could give them all to me then,
over a 30-hour period, plus a Kitty Hawk and a Hancock, plus the 7th Air Force.
Meantime, the president has sent Alexander Haig and Henry Kissinger over.
Alexander Haig comes under president and wants to know from you personally, can you hold it?
That's what Haig asked you?
Yeah, he said, the president wanted me to ask you personally, and I have to pass the president.
I said, I don't know.
You'd like a beer?
Yeah.
Beer.
Thank you.
So, I said, I don't know, Al.
I said, God damn it, if I can get some damn firepower here to support it, I said, I think I can.
He said, well, the president's going to give you a third star if you can do it.
Really?
That's what Hank said to you right there on the spot?
That's what Hank said to me.
I said, I'm not interested in any goddamn third star.
I said, I'll see what the hell I can do here.
I've got to have the damn firepower.
I had four battalions of infantry left in the 3rd Brigade of the 1st Cavalry Division.
and a handful of helicopters.
And I wasn't permitted to use these infantrymen.
So Abrams comes out They were Americans.
Americans, yeah.
Everybody else had gone home, except a hell of a big lot of headquarters, about 30,000 civilians and military left in headquarters there.
And that's the reason why they didn't want the damn high command captured.
Remember, they had gotten into Saigon with a hell of a lot less strength in 1968.
But I had no goddamn strength at all.
I wasn't going to allow the son of a bitch that's in there.
So, well, Abrams comes out to see me, and he said...
He flew out?
Yeah, in his helicopter, he came out to see me from his headquarters down in Saigon.
He said, Secretary of Defense and the President wants to continue withdrawal of forces, drawdown.
He said, and you want more air power?
I said, yeah.
He said, what will you trade for a Marine Air Group?
I said, I'll trade you two battalions of infantry, but those guys are out there protecting the rocket belt to keep rockets from falling on your head down there.
And I said, I don't think you're going to get any.
I think all those rocket forces are all up around me at Unlock.
You haven't had any rounds in on you recently.
I said, I'll trade you two battalions of infantry for a Marine air wing.
He said, well, hell, there's only 900 people in that Marine air wing.
I said, yeah, I don't give a damn how many people we got.
I just want the damn airplanes.
36 airplanes, or 24, 20.
Yeah, about 36 airplanes.
A-4s, A-4s.
So, that was the 12th Marine Air Group.
So, commanded by Colonel Dan Mocko,
who should have been a Marine Brigadier, but never was, and retired as a colonel.
God damn, what a phenomenal guy.
Anyway, he said, well, by God, I want you.
